M1036.name: Account Use Policies
M1036.desc: Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.

M1015.name: Active Directory Configuration
M1015.desc: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

M1049.name: Antivirus/Antimalware
M1049.desc: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

M1013.name: Application Developer Guidance
M1013.desc: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.

M1048.name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
M1048.desc: Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.

M1047.name: Audit
M1047.desc: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

M1040.name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
M1040.desc: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

M1046.name: Boot Integrity
M1046.desc: Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

M1045.name: Code Signing
M1045.desc: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

M1043.name: Credential Access Protection
M1043.desc: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

M1053.name: Data Backup
M1053.desc: Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

M1057.name: Data Loss Prevention
M1057.desc: Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.[1]

M1042.name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
M1042.desc: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

M1055.name: Do Not Mitigate
M1055.desc: This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.

M1041.name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
M1041.desc: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

M1039.name: Environment Variable Permissions
M1039.desc: Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.

M1038.name: Execution Prevention
M1038.desc: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

M1050.name: Exploit Protection
M1050.desc: Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.

M1037.name: Filter Network Traffic
M1037.desc: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

M1035.name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
M1035.desc: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

M1034.name: Limit Hardware Installation
M1034.desc: Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices.

M1033.name: Limit Software Installation
M1033.desc: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

M1032.name: Multi-factor Authentication
M1032.desc: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

M1031.name: Network Intrusion Prevention
M1031.desc: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

M1030.name: Network Segmentation
M1030.desc: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

M1028.name: Operating System Configuration
M1028.desc: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

M1027.name: Password Policies
M1027.desc: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

M1056.name: Pre-compromise
M1056.desc: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

M1026.name: Privileged Account Management
M1026.desc: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

M1025.name: Privileged Process Integrity
M1025.desc: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

M1029.name: Remote Data Storage
M1029.desc: Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.

M1022.name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
M1022.desc: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

M1044.name: Restrict Library Loading
M1044.desc: Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.

M1024.name: Restrict Registry Permissions
M1024.desc: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

M1021.name: Restrict Web-Based Content
M1021.desc: Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.

M1054.name: Software Configuration
M1054.desc: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

M1020.name: SSL/TLS Inspection
M1020.desc: Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.

M1019.name: Threat Intelligence Program
M1019.desc: A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.

M1051.name: Update Software
M1051.desc: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

M1052.name: User Account Control
M1052.desc: Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

M1018.name: User Account Management
M1018.desc: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

M1017.name: User Training
M1017.desc: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

M1016.name: Vulnerability Scanning
M1016.desc: Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.
